Ask HN: What's your favorite software-free keyboard and mouse?
text:
I've lost all patience with Logitech. I currently use their mechanical keyboard and the new version of the MX Master mouse. The hardware is good, but the software is obnoxious. It's not unusual to see 5 or 6 Logitech processes running. In my opinion that's ridiculous, so I'm looking for good replacements that require zero software.

What's your favorite (software-free) keyboard and mouse for programming?

Ask HN: Low/No JavaScript Resources?
text:
I would really like to see a resource which presents the low/no js tools and pros/cons of each. Does anything like this exist? I am talking tools like htmx, unpoly, hotwire or slim js frameworks such as alpine or stimulus.

Ideally would contain:

  - overview of framework
  - link to framework
  - integrations with backend (Django, Rails, Laravel, etc)
  - sample app code (same app implented in each)
  - guidance - for example, hotwire is more rails specific from what I can see

Ask HN: What happened to vanilla HTML/CSS/JS development?
text:
I'm not a web developer, but I dabble in it because I find it interesting. I went through some courses like The Odin Project and others to learn the basics of HTML/CSS/JS, and I thought it made a lot of sense: HTML structures the page, CSS handles the style, and JS handles the functionality.

However, after working for software companies for a few years, it seems like almost nobody uses these technologies in the way they're presented on websites like w3schools to make web applications. Instead, they use component-based frameworks like React. To me, these frameworks seem way more complicated than HTML/CSS/JS, and I don't understand what problem they're trying to solve. What makes the trade-off of all that extra complexity and abstraction worth it? Aren't HTML/CSS/JS perfectly fine and time-tested tools for web development on their own?

Why EDI and API are different sides of the same coin
text:
Have you ever wondered if those "EDI vs. API" articles are legit and why they got it all wrong?!? EDI and API are different references to the same concept, e.g., they are essentially the same thing.

From Wikipedia:

Electronic data interchange (EDI) is the concept of businesses electronically communicating information

An application programming interface (API) is a way for two or more computer programs to communicate with each other

Our "Why we created our EDI API?" (https://support.edifabric.com/hc/en-us/articles/360027505811-Why-we-created-EDI-Developer-API) article offers a different perspective on the "EDI vs.API" narrative.

Ask HN: What are some effective ways to attract donations for a dog shelter?
text:
I am sorry in advance, this is 100% irrelevant for a place like HackerNews. But this is the first place with so many knowledgeable and technically advanced people.

If anyone cares to come up with a piece of advice, I will really appreciate that.

There is a dog shelter in the city I live in that has absolutely no sponsors or support from the government. Yet, it's the only place known to shelter dogs all around the country, trying to save them from being killed or dying from hunger.

I donate money to that shelter almost every day. What's more, my own dog is from that shelter.

https://hayotislife.com/help-en

I am wondering whether you have any experience with raising donations for such places. I don't even have any ideas but really want to help them financially. Right now, they don't even have funds for food and medicaments.

There was a place on Reddit for donations, but they have very strict rules regarding the required reputation so I can't post there.

Are there any other options?
